title: M. M. Mustapha
text:
<a href="Al-Haj">Al-Haj</a> Meeralebbe Poddy Mohamed Mustapha (10 July 1924– 3 October 2000) was a Ceylonese lawyer and politician.
Meeralebbe Poddy Mohamed Mustapha was born in Nintavur on 16 July 1924, the son of Meeralebbe Podi <a href="Vanniar%20%28Chieftain%29">Vanniar</a> and Meera Ummah. He received his early education in Nintavur, before attending <a href="Methodist%20Central%20College">Batticaloa Methodist Central College</a>. Following which he graduated from the <a href="Sri%20Lanka%20Law%20College">Ceylon Law College</a> as an <a href="Advocate%23Sri%20Lanka">advocate</a>. Mustapha then passed the Inter-Law Exam at the <a href="City%20Law%20School">London University</a>.
In 1948 he commenced as a lawyer, practicing in <a href="Batticaloa">Batticaloa</a>.
Mustapha married the eldest daughter of <a href="Gate%20Mudaliyar">Gate Mudaliyar</a> <a href="M.%20S.%20Kariapper">Mohammed Samsudeen Kariapper</a>, the chairman of <a href="Kalmunai">Kalmunai</a> Town Council and the member for <a href="Kalmunai%20Electoral%20District">Kalmunai</a>.
He first ran for <a href="Parliament%20of%20Ceylon">parliament</a> at the <a href="1952%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">1952 Ceylonese parliamentary election</a> in the <a href="Pottuvil%20Electoral%20District">Pottuvil electorate</a>, held in May 1952, running as the <a href="Illankai%20Tamil%20Arasu%20Kachchi">Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi</a> (Federal Party) candidate. He was narrowly defeated by the sitting member, <a href="M.%20M.%20Ebrahim">Meerakuddy Mohamed Ebrahim</a>, with a margin of 559 votes.
At the <a href="1956%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">3rd parliamentary election</a>, held in April 1956, Ebrahim chose not to run due to poor health and Mustapha was successful in securing the seat for the Federal Party, receiving 8,355 votes (51.8% of the total vote) defeating his nearest opponent, M. I. M. Abdul Majeed, by 3,729 votes. He resigned from the Federal Party in 1958 as he opposed the party's proposed <a href="satyagraha">satyagraha</a> movement. In June 1959 <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Sri%20Lanka">Prime Minister</a> <a href="S.%20W.%20R.%20D.%20Bandaranaike">S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike</a> appointed Mustapha as the <a href="Parliamentary%20Secretary">Parliamentary Secretary</a> to the <a href="Minister%20of%20Finance%20%28Sri%20Lanka%29">Minister of Finance</a> in his <a href="S.%20W.%20R.%20D.%20Bandaranaike%20cabinet">cabinet</a>. Following Bandaranaike's assassination in September, <a href="Wijeyananda%20Dahanayake">Wijeyananda Dahanayake</a> who took over as Prime Minister appointed Mustapha as the Minister of Finance in November, becoming the first Muslim Minister of Finance.
At the <a href="March%201960%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">4th parliamentary election</a>, held in March 1960, Mustapha contested the newly created seat of <a href="Nintavur%20Electoral%20District">Nintavur</a>. He failed to get elected and was defeated by <a href="M.%20I.%20M.%20Abdul%20Majeed">M. I. M. Abdul Majeed</a> by 4,627 votes. He re-contested the seat at the subsequent <a href="July%201960%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">parliamentary elections in July</a>, where he lost again to Majeed, this time by 7,776 votes. He was ultimately successful at the <a href="1965%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">6th parliamentary election</a>, held in March 1965, as the <a href="United%20National%20Party">United National Party</a> candidate, defeating Majeed by 4,3899 votes. Following the election he was appointed by Prime Minister <a href="Dudley%20Senanayake">Dudley Senanayake</a> as the Parliamentary Secretary to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Social%20Empowerment%2C%20Welfare%20and%20Kandyan%20Heritage%23Ministers">Minister of Social Services</a>.
Mustapha was re-elected at the <a href="1970%20Ceylonese%20parliamentary%20election">7th parliamentary election</a>, held in May 1970, by only 75 votes, securing 13,481 votes (49% of the total vote). He switched political allegiances and joined the <a href="Sri%20Lanka%20Freedom%20Party">Sri Lanka Freedom Party</a>. In 1976 he was appointed as the deputy <a href="Ministry%20of%20Justice%20%28Sri%20Lanka%29%23List%20of%20Ministers">Minister of Justice</a> by Prime Minister <a href="Sirimavo%20Bandaranaike">Sirimavo Bandaranaike</a> after she elevated <a href="Ratnasiri%20Wickremanayake">Ratnasiri Wickremanayake</a> to the position of Minister.
At the <a href="1977%20Sri%20Lankan%20parliamentary%20election">1977 Sri Lankan parliamentary election</a> he contested the <a href="Pottuvil%20Electoral%20District">Pottuvil electorate</a> as the Sri Lanka Freedom Party candidate. Whilst he polled 22,378 votes (25% of the total vote), he was defeated by the United National Party candidate, <a href="A.%20M.%20Mohamed%20Jalaldeen">A. M. Mohamed Jalaldeen</a>, who received 30,318 votes (34% of the total vote) and the <a href="Tamil%20United%20Liberation%20Front">Tamil United Liberation Front</a> candidate, <a href="M.%20Canagaratnam">Mylvaganam Canagaratnam</a>, with 23,990 votes.
He was a member of the <a href="Eastern%20University%2C%20Sri%20Lanka">Eastern University</a> Council.
